abstracts.cdata!:
In the metropolitan Manila area,
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            has supported two utilities in expanding affordable and
            efficient water and sewerage services to benefit some
            107,000 poor households since 1997, relying on an approach
            that encourages private sector investment and support and
            greater community involvement. Lessons learned from the
            IBRD-financed projects with Manila Water Co. Inc (MWCI) are
            distilled into the following: community sanitation projects
            can be successful in low-income communities, provided that
            regular and timely public information campaigns are
            carefully conducted and the benefits well-explained; land
            for sewerage facilities was difficult or costly to secure.
            Problems associated with land acquisition primarily caused
            project delays. Careful planning for land acquisition must
            be made part of the project development process; and final
            options for project implementation must be arrived at
            considering not only the technical and financial aspects but
            also the required institutional arrangements and the social
            and other risks.
